pros: Supportive environment, good benefits, great supervisors
cons: Wish I had more opportunities to teach with them.

review_title: Good for a foot in the door into higher ed
pros: People Opportunities for personal development
cons: Low pay Students can be very demanding Outdated systems and policies

review_title: This place should be shut down
job_title: Academic Advisor in Orchard Park, NY
pros: Coworkers are fun. That’s the only good part.
cons: Terrible, conniving management. Do not care about employees or anything in their lives, including COVID-19. They let students waste way too much money on poor education and push them to keep going when they are perpetually failing or don’t have the proper technology. Student Services is just another call center, and there is no real relationships made with students, only call quotas for stupid reports. Everything is micromanaged, and the managers get annoyed when they actually have to train or answer questions. There are minimal promotion opportunities. Pay is abysmal compared to other colleges, but the work is overwhelming. Good work is punished with more work, and poor work is ignored. Their solution to terrible employees is just to give their work to good employees without more pay. When someone leaves, advisors have to double up on work, again without any extra benefit or pay. Honestly, it was a toxic, traumatic job environment, and I would never recommend stepping foot in there as an employee or a student.

review_title: If you want a saled job
pros: if you like sales, this is the job for you
cons: if you hate sales, this is all this company cares about

job_title: Online Admissions Representative in Orchard Park, NY
pros: The people you work alongside help you get through your day. There is a lot of turn over so you get to meet a lot of new people over your time employed.
cons: It’s sales at a call center. You are pushed to enroll students into programs that they will more than likely not succeed in just so you can meet your enrollment goals that get higher and higher each start date. September enrollment is the worst time of the year due to the sheer amount of calls you get in a day. 20+ for 6-10 minutes each. Hope you don’t need to go to the bathroom. Favorites are chosen and are the only ones rewarded. If you are having a bad start with your sales numbers, your manager will for sure let you know. Whether privately or in front of your co-workers. Tuition cost is ridiculous for an online school.

pros: Encouraging and inclusive team. Clear deadlines.
cons: Strict discussion guidelines and grading deadlines.

pros: Good people to work with, a fair degree of autonomy in the work, and professional office environment.

pros: This job prepares you for working with the public, building strong relationships and they even allow you to attend there as an eemployee. They genuinely care for students. Great management and people to work with.

pros: It's more than minimum wage

My experience with Bryant & Stratton College was very enjoyable and I would recommend it to anyone.
cons: Saturday shifts once in a while would be the only con I can think of. This was a great place to work.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Virginia Beach, VA
pros:
Friendly faculty and staff who have a passion for what they do

Accreditation

Admissions is the "golden" department, and the majority of our all associate meetings focus on praising them.

Unethical managers
Leaders who do not build relationships with their teams

The culture has changed over the many years I was employed here.  It went from a  family atmosphere to a "dog-eat dog-world"!

job_title: Enrollment Services Representative in Orchard Park, NY
pros: You know when you read a job review titled “Great Place to Work” and you think to yourself, “there’s no way that’s actually true”? Well, this one is! Professional work environment filled with positive vibes. Coworkers are super friendly and always willing to lend a hand when needed. Managers go out of their way to help employees learn, grow, and advance (even if it means them leaving the department)! Employees are acknowledged and appreciated for their efforts and contributions; positive reinforcement is continuous. Managers and Coaches create fun yet challenging contests, games, etc. to keep things interesting! I’m very BIG on effective communication and managers take the cake on that one! Very transparent and upfront about expectations, policy changes, etc. Family orientated company; always flexible if issues arise. And last, but not least, the job itself is very intrinsically motivating! From the students we’re able to speak with, the stories we’re able to hear, the lives were actually able to help change - it’s awesome! To get to go to work each day, knowing that I get to play even a small part in helping students achieve their goals, I think headlining this review as a “Great Place to Work” is pretty spot on!
cons: I don’t have anything for this Con field

job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Buffalo, NY
pros: Great people to work with
cons: Not a lot of room to advance

job_title: Assistant Track and Field Coach in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Trying to expand their athletic department, which is great.
cons: A lot of growing to do.

pros: You will gain teaching experience and there are some really wonderful people employed there.
cons: Where do I begin? They expect so much out of faculty and mid-level management- the ridiculous credit loads (3x a year since they go through the summer), extremely high health insurance costs, virtually no benefits for retirement from the college itself (they might as well not give anything, making 5 dollars quarterly from the college as "matching" is stupid). They have this ridiculous credentialing policy- news flash, you're not Harvard, so maybe you should just accept that not everyone takes these courses with matching titles as a grad student and that people are competent in their fields. The only programs they care about are the healthcare programs, everyone else is an afterthought. Their treatment of students, staff, faculty, and management is abysmal at best, unethical at worst. I wouldn't recommend working at this place to anyone.

job_title: Contact Center Representative in Buffalo, NY
pros:
•  The Contact Center is a warm and friendly environment to start out at the  college. It is a great place to network and learn about the college. You will be challenged to make a large amount of outbound calls and quickly build rapport with students! 
• Management is friendly and flexible.
• Schedules are flexible.
• Lots of room for growth.
cons:
• It is easy to become burnt out.
• Repetitive work with very little variety.
• Often changes are expressed last minute; however there is an ability to take a step back from any task and ask questions.

job_title: Online Academic Advisor in Orchard Park, NY
pros: I loved my coworkers and the building is in a nice neighborhood.
cons:
Low Pay
Night, Holidays, Weekends, all for no extra pay
Make you wait for benefits, then tell you it's "not in the budget"
They don't care about employees at all. I gave 5 years of service, was the only advisor meeting goals, and they didn't even so much as give me a "great job."
Faculty, staff, and students are all just a number. They do not run like a school that cares about their students. All they care about are numbers, money, and how to increase their marketing strategy to make more money. Everyone is easily replaceable. 
They have extremely outdated technology and when they do update it, their systems are outdated and the new technology doesn't work. 
You WILL be micromanaged, you will not have any opportunities for professional development, and any benefits that are offered to you (such as tuition reimbursement) comes with a catch that's not worth the benefit in the long run.

pros: A last resort for students pursuing a higher education.
cons: I wouldn't recommend this institution to prospective students or anyone seeking employment. Students are just looked as "money walking in the door" and recruited with unethical tactics. Employees are highly underappreciated unless you work for Admissions or are close with members in upper management. I've heard employers inform that they either deny or think twice before hiring someone (including students seeking internships) from Bryant & Stratton because they "don't want that mess over here." I strongly advise that you do your research before considering this institution for employment or obtaining a higher education.

review_title: Need more focus on hard-working part-time faculty members.
pros: The administration always supports the faculty in their time of need. They offer flexible course schedules. The student-teacher ratio is wonderful, and it allows the faculty members to connect with students and give them full time and opportunity to master the materials taught in the courses. The courses allow faculty flexibility in making assignments.
cons: There is too much administrative stuff going on. A lot of standardized tests and programs are implemented, at the cost of class time provided by instructors. Instructors who work part time are not rewarded for their hard work and effort with the students. Instructors who have clearly been failing to meet the necessary standards for student achievement fly under the radar and are not held accountable.

review_title: For Profit Colleges, the good, the bad and the ugly.
pros: Students who might not get into a traditional college will be welcomed at Bryant & Stratton College.  Each program does have a student-led organization.
cons:
Very money and numbers driven organization.  Some truly care about the students and want them to succeed, others are there because it is a job.  

Information technology students are no longer given vouchers to take an IT industry certification, yet companies are demanding certifications to even get in the door.

Cost to attend B&S College is very high, students could attend a state college for less money.

Students are not encouraged to dress appropriately, they are just glad the students attend, however it is not a good look when you have corporations or business representatives on campus.

A significant number of students start out taking 1-2 remedial classes that don't count towards graduating, but pay college tuition prices for those classes.

job_title: Contact Center Representative in Buffalo, NY
pros: All of the staff are very nice and extremely helpful. This being my first job, I couldn't ask for anything better. Bryant & Stratton has a Professional atmosphere with many people who make working enjoyable.
cons: I think we drive some students away from our constant calls. We should be calling potential students twice a day with hours in between calls. I've had a lead be upset because he was called 3 times in the hour. That alone, will make people not want to enroll. We're a great college and we do so much more than other schools with our personalized experience. However, I believe it's the little things companies do to set them apart from their competitors. Maybe something as small as just calling a little less often, can bring in more leads.

job_title: Head Math Tutor in Cleveland, OH
pros: They give you a Flexible schedule, and they are willing to work with your schedule if you are in school.
cons: They are constantly cutting hours each semester, and have high turnover rate.

review_title: Take it only if you have to
job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Orchard Park, NY
pros: It can be a good place to learn the basics and move on if higher education is your goal
cons:
So many. All offices are treated as admissions. They would exclusively recruit students who were unprepared for college. Admissions reps would frequently use high pressure tactics taking advantage of students lack of knowledge and insecurities. Having to help these students with financial aid truly made me feel guilty. 
Management was disrespectful and unprofessional. They would frequently play employees off each other and berate them in front of everyone. Because of this you will find turnover to be very high. It is nearly impossible for an organization to run well when no one has experience and most of the staff is new. My 2 years there were the works 2 years of my working life.The treatment received was not work the meager pay I received. If you are considering working for this company I encourage you to use it for experience and keep your job search going.

pros: It's a totally unique environment for teaching. Small classes, ability to provide strong support for students, and support from the administration. The management style gives you academic freedom to execute the curriculum in creative ways. More than any other teaching job I've had, I feel like I have impacted student lives.
cons: It's a branch of a larger chain of colleges, so there's a lot of bureaucracy that sometimes gets in the way of the college's mission.

pros: I love teaching and B&S gave me that opportunity. The Hampton Campus is nice and the students are sometimes  a challengr but....I love what I do!
cons: Inconsistent pay schedule which is annoying. I'd like to get paid in a timely manner for my work, time, and effort. No payroll department to speak of to ensure you're paid. The students, who are very much ADULT are not held accountable for doing their work or held to a high standard...BUT it is a "for profit" university... However, I expected at least a smidge of accountability. I'm on seriously considering leaving aftet next semester if things are not consistent with the pay....Ilove my work but i don't work for FREE unless its at church.

review_title: Good starting pay, nowhere to go from there.
pros:
- Flexible Schedule
- Starting pay is above industry average
- Fulfilling work and satisfying work/life balance
cons:
- Depending on department, room for advancement can be limited
- Structured minimal percentage pay raise across the board, provides little incentive to overachieve
- System's management does not understand what it is like to operate on a campus level

pros: The faculty and staff are hard working and wonderful to work with. The job itself is actually rewarding.
cons: No room for advancement. Promote from outside the company. Too many managers to answer to. Newer, less experienced people tend to make more money than established people that have had a record of success. Some managers are in positions or roles that they should not be in. The working hours are dreadful, and most holidays are workdays.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in West Buxton, ME
pros: Many instructors are top notch.
cons: Instructors are pushed to pass below-par students.  Instructors are chastised for insisting on proper classroom behavior.  Students are only considered money to the administration.  Students have no clue the proper attire for business.  This institution began a "dumbed down" grading system when I was employed, during the 2012 school year.  I believe this was an attempt to keep students in school, keep the college in the green so to speak.  In other words, students who wouldn't have a prayer of keeping a job in the current market are being helped to pass courses by a dumbed-down grading system, when they obviously do not have the capability or desire to learn the material.

pros: Rewarding role, work life balance, Deans are really amazing.
cons: 100% acceptance rate means you have people that should not be in school.  Faculty at times champion a pass for students that have no right for that ask (30% average is a hard fail). Sense of entitlement “I paid tuition therefore I deserve an A” is getting more prevalent through the years, this is not generational.

pros: They trained you well when you start so you feel prepared when you start working with students.
cons:
Horrible work life balance
Promotions were nearly non-existent
They tell you that you just work a few Saturdays's but it works out to be 24 of the 52 Saturdays a year. 
They fought you when you asked for time off and would give you a hard time for missing work when it was approved. 
Never gave you opportunities to grow even when you asked.

review_title: Good way to gain experience; Not recommended for a career
pros: Great faculty and staff; Strong curriculum; Many students who have come to learn and are willing to exert the required effort to be successful, graduate and enter their chosen field; Decent technology; Small setting, so students get more individual attention from instructors and staff; Student-centered philosophy;
cons: Low pay; Horrible benefits; No regard for work/life balance of faculty and staff; Top down management; Rampant favoritism and cronyism; Too profit driven;

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Orchard Park, NY
pros:
They pay in USD, which is nice.

Your fellow instructors are generally friendly and helpful.

Many students come from disadvantaged backgrounds, and the successes (though rare) are really rewarding.
cons:
Aside from the predatory admissions practices and exorbitant prices they charge students for a less-than-stellar education, they:

Change classroom policies quickly and without warning

Moved many gen. ed. classes to an online only format, without adequately preparing the students (many of whom don't have regular home access to a computer),

Constantly send reminders about retention, sending mixed messages about whether they're linking retention rates to your continued employment. This obviously creates pressure to pass students who would fail,

Undermine faculty decisions about class policies (like late submission policies) in order to manipulate retention,

Fail to put together contracts in a timely fashion

review_title: In Milwaukee, a pretty decent place to work.
pros: There are quite a few pros to working at Milwaukee's Bryant & Stratton. Expect a lot of autonomy and freedom with your curriculum, a flexible schedule, and a lot of support. Management is helpful and supportive. I can honestly say that at this employer, I have had the best, most positive, most supportive co-workers and bosses. Most employees are leaders and will help you with anything you ask. For me, out of several different employers, I have had the best time here. I hope to stay for many years.
cons:
Many people state that the pay is low. Unfortunately, their wage is pretty standard in Milwaukee. Most professions in Milwaukee is low compared to the rest of the state or country. For example, a starting RN in Madison, WI starts at $31/hr and in Milwaukee, WI starts around $22/hr. 
The student base entering the campuses are lower functioning and can have a helpless attitude. Milwaukee's culture is very unique, especially students coming from Milwaukee Public School. Be expected to be very helpful and to work outside class hours answering a multitude of student emails, meeting with students, and doing everything you can to help them be successful. The culture at these campuses are also last minute. Many things you need may be completed after a date where it can be useful. If you are a type A personality, be aware you may have to change your plan often to accommodate other's work.

review_title: Top Employer in Western New York
pros: Strong, Fair Senior Leadership trickles down throughout the organization, encouraging a fun, progressive and productive work environment. We continue to grow, year over year, resulting in many new faces, positions, and opportunities. Salaries/benefit packages are solid; Growth Paths for just about every position in the company...and we actually PROMOTE from within! Culture and Morale are highly valued and positive. Absolutely a top employer in Western New York!
cons: Nothing I can think of that's noteworthy.

pros: I have worked at state institutions and truly appreciate the one on one opportunity to connect with students.  A family atmosphere is cultivated and there is flexibility with schedules.  I love the many activities offered which allow interaction with students.
cons: There are some employees who are simply not happy and take that out on others.  Of course anywhere you go there are those whose mission is to cause strife.

pros: Good organization and management at the Hampton Campus.   The leadership is really devoted to student success.  Instructors are give sufficient latitude in delivering content so long as core learning objectives are met.
cons: Very low pay. I have worked at siMilan schools with a lesser workload and received more money.

review_title: my perfect job gone due to illness
job_title: High School Student Recruiter in Chicago, IL
pros: I made my own schedule and received many call backs.  The job works with my personality and it is something I would wish to do again.
cons: I am a great presenter and I do it well.  I was given many accolades that others have not reached.  I trained the staff and after they fired me they had to change the program because there was no one able to do the job as well as I.

job_title: Level I Admissions Advisor in North Olmsted, OH
pros:
Lots of paid time off
Job security 
Free tuition after 1 year
cons:
Constantly discouraged from taking time off
Not enough sick time
Strict guidelines how and when you can use your time off
Told there's room for growth but only if you continuously add to your debt/education
Job blocking
Tuition is extremely expensive, $26,000 = AAS, $50,000 = BA
Little to no breathing room - once one semester's enrollment ends another immediately begins 
Stress to pay ratio not good

review_title: As others have said, only if you have to
pros: It will allow you to get your foot in the door of education.
cons: It is all about numbers and as students leave to attend better colleges or fail from their own lack of academic progress it becomes the employees fault. Management utilizes mind games to students and employees with multiple "backdoor" conversations, you could never trust anyone, EVER...

review_title: A pretty good place to work
job_title: Contact Center Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Management in the Contact Center is fantastic! Awesome benefits and flexible scheduling as well. Regular employee appreciation events help boost morale. Lots of opportunity for advancement within the department and outside the department.
cons: The new-hire trainer for all departments reflects poorly on the college as a whole--doesn't speak/write/even spell correctly, which makes this being an institution of higher education seem questionable.

pros: Southtowns campus has a very caring staff and you truly have the opportunity to help students find employment upon graduation. Students get out what they put in, as with anything in life.
cons: Work can get tedious, as with any inside sales role. Hours are difficult as they require late nights a few times a week.

review_title: Overall, great company with excellent benefits and an opportunity for work/life balance.
pros: Family oriented with a work hard/ play hard attitude.
cons: Promotion opportunities are based on "friend"status rather then performance and merit.

job_title: IT Associate in North Evans, NY
pros: Very friendly staff that will go out of their way to help if needed. Everyone knows everyone else bu first name.
cons: Not very much room for advancement and some employees that shouldn't still be employed are because of connections through family.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: I enjoyed being around my peers. They were very motivational and kept me there as long as I stayed.
cons: This location is completely unorganized and inefficient for a new person to thrive. There is a lack of good training, follow through and follow up. Management does not genuinely care. I put in several complaints through HR and there was little to no action. I ended up resigning because this location has a reputation for not properly addressing exactly what my complaint is. Also the pay for this position is very low.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Orchard Park, NY
pros: Hard to think of any at this point. There is no one else left to say I enjoyed working with. Market and system managers should start paying attention to campuses with NO EMPLOYEES
cons: They are only looking for Yes Men, warm bodies to use until they have fulfilled their need. Worked there for almost 5 years and there was not a single promotion from my campus, not a single one. Raises are non existent, and appreciation is even further away.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Small classes; lots of support for students and faculty; friendly and pro-active atmosphere; high retention rates, and most students find work in their desired fields.
cons: Salary is fairly low, and it is not administration's fault: somehow there doesn't seem to be enough financing to provide well deserved raises and the like.

job_title: Systems Curriculum Manager in Getzville, NY
pros: 2 weeks of paid time off to start, goes up to 3 weeks after 5 years, plus 6 floating holidays. Decent pay. Medical/dental/vision insurance available.
cons: No job security. Only 4 sick days per year. Your amount of flexibility completely depends on who your manager is.  The insurance is expensive. The company also always cares more about the bottom line than about its students or employees.

pros: It was enriching to help the students. Staff really cares and are fun to work with. They offer tuition reimbursement.
cons: Management is disconnected and only focused on enrollment numbers. Decisions are short-sighted and change often.

review_title: Bryant & Stratton.....Only if you have to
job_title: Subject Area Coordinator (Program Chair) in Parma, OH
pros: Gives you a foot in the door if you are trying to break into the academic teaching arena.
cons: very low pay, extermely high benifits package ($1100/mo for family coverage), lack of focus, lack of organization, lack of academic rigor. Instructors even adjuncts are made to attend meetings with no focus, same dead topics and no resolutions.

pros: This position gets busy, however it's easy to do the work and there are some staff members that make work enjoyable.
cons: There's a lot of unprofessional superiors who gossip a lot which makes the work environment uncomfortable. Also there are some staff members who try to find every little thing to get you in trouble which also makes it a hard working environment.

review_title: If you value working for an ethical organization, BSC is NOT the place for you
pros:
Despite the dreadful working environment, there are still some excellent, dedicated employees who care about students and their success. 
I’m sure some employees get great salaries—management and Admissions (sales) being prime examples.
cons:
Constant cuts to staff, layoffs occurred almost every term.
Making money always prioritized over helping students.
Little room for advancement in many positions.
Student facing staff not valued (campus didn’t provide even basic safety precautions).

pros: Co-workers, for the most part, are incredibly supportive and great team atmosphere. Small environment provides opportunity to get to know the students. Everyone genuinely cares about the students' success which makes it enjoyable to come to work everyday.
cons:
Benefits are horrible if you aren't in NY area. Way too expensive!!  
Not a lot of training. As with any company, can become cliqueish at times.

pros: More affordable than many may think. B&S is a for-profit college but is still within many prospects' budget.
cons: They need to be more transparent upfront regarding student loans, grants, and financial aid packages.

job_title: Career Services Advisor in Milwaukee, WI
pros: There is opportunity, when working in Career Services at BSC to be creative and innovative in achieving your goals. Each student provides a unique opportunity to find a career solution.
cons: Students can be challenging to work with. Many have some sort of criminal background so job placement is sometimes difficult.

pros: I have met some of the nicest co-workers here, made life long friends.
cons:
Terrible pay, completely absent management, pre-made classes leave no choice to instructor with laughable material, spelling and numeric mistakes on most documents, admissions blatantly lies and admits students unable to pass, one program manager oversees multiple programs and is unqualified, lack of communication, lack of respect, school that is run like a business with absolutely no focus on quality education, actually refers to students as "customers" in emails. 

Seriously if you care about education, don't work here, you will be appalled.

pros: You will make a difference in the lives of students.  The school is dedicated to helping students get positions in their field of study.
cons: Very few promotion opportunities are available for employees.  The Education reimbursement plan is exclusionary.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: At the campus level, very dedicated personnel.
cons: This is an inbred company at the top. HR at the corporate level is extremely inadequate as well as pretty much all of them. Completely out of touch. Outcomes do not take precedence over enrollments.

job_title: Financial Aid Director in Hampton, VA
pros: Satisfaction helping students who otherwise may not be able to receive an education.
cons: The cost of the college is very challenging for students. Student loan borrowing is at an all time high.

review_title: New management drove it to the ground
pros: Pay check clears, training from vendors
cons: Local management went to the dogs after a few promotions, They no longer cared about employees just numbers.

review_title: Great people to work with, and the college cares about students and employees alike
job_title: Student Life Impactor in Orchard Park, NY
pros: Intelligent, helpful people to work with, meaningful work, not some billion dollar corporate giant, opportunities for advancement.
cons: Not getting rich working in higher education, if that is what motivates you.

pros: Great co-workers and some good management. Get to help students who would not be successful else where
cons: Hours, pay, and benefits. Treated like call center employees even though most are professionals

job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Buffalo, NY
pros: Solid benefits, tuition reimbursement, a good amount of PTO
cons: Long hours, upper management can be blind to how things are really going, dealing with college kids is often a challenge

review_title: An OK place to work, but not a great company
pros: A lot of good people that care about their job and students.
cons:
At corporate level they are just interested in making money.
Benefits are not good. 
Pay is neither good nor bad.

pros: Customer Service driven and focus is on the students
cons: Little room for professional growth. Everything is numbers driven. Does not promote true diversity and fair treatment across the board.

review_title: Can’t wait to see this place shut down.
pros:
Teaching experience 
Wants me to write more but I just can’t- working at this place was the most toxic thing I could have done to myself.
cons:
Horrible benefits
Poor treatment of program directors and faculty- if you didn’t pass enough people you actually got dinged on your “score”
Micromanaged by everyone in administration
Highly unqualified upper level administration
Con their students, which should come of no surprise

pros: modern, efficient,  caring, really believe in education.
cons: low pay, inability to guarantee classes, too many meetings, no pay for prep which can be considerable for new hires.

review_title: Helping students learn and study course that are taking which include Interactive Media, Information Technology, Math
pros: Interacting with students to help them learn the skills and knowledge needed to work in the fields of Interactive Media, Information Technology, Math Course
cons: Based on the needs of students

job_title: Work Study Receptionist in Eastlake, OH
pros: I worked as a work study as I was a student there and it was a great place to work.
cons: Very quiet at night especially in the summer. And is very cold in the winter but other then that there's nothing to complain about!

pros:
Fun when your campus is doing well
Depending on boss, flexible schedule
Rewarding to help the right students
Pays better than other admissions jobs
cons:
All about numbers and enrollments
Proprietary education is sketchy
Ethical issues

pros: you get a paycheck- that's about it
cons:
-upper management  does not respect employees
-upper management will switch employees titles and move employees into positions they did not interview or sign-up for without speaking to employee beforehand
-upper management does not provide opportunity for employee to grow, does not try to teach them anything

pros: Flexible schedule, standardized curriculum means less planning. Usually small class sizes.
cons: All resources directed at increasing revenue streams, not "individualized learning." Their priorities are clearly profit, not student outcomes, which should be obvious to any one familiar with for-profit institutions. Management (and it is management) pressures instructors to improve attendance because it is linked to their eventual revenue streams. Lowest pay for adjuncts going.

pros: Good pay, classy office environment
cons: Sales-oriented, short sighted plan of management, If you do not reach your enrollment goal, they will let you go and look elsewhere

pros: Creative, dynamic environment. Never boring - never the same day twice.  Allows employees input and the ability to make changes in our students' lives.
cons: Rapidity of change to keep up with the changing world of academia.

job_title: Contact Center Representative in Buffalo, NY
pros: Bryant & Stratton College is a great place to work.  The staff is very friendly and there is some areas of opportunity to move up and grow in the departments.
cons: I don't have any cons.

pros: Good compensation and benefits, flexible hours, option to work from home with bad weather
cons: Unable to work from home everyday.  They job I did really did not require me to be in an office.  I worked alone everyday anyway.

pros: Very friendly  Good students,well motivated . Pay and class scheduling is good
cons: Poor IT support  All  decisions are made at corporate officies

pros: The people are great! The students are the primary concern overall great culture.
cons: Work some holidays but you get a comp day for it so its not bad

job_title: Business Office Assistant/Financial Aid Advisor in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Not much.......just don't bother working there.
cons: Too many to list. Bad place to work. Will over work you, burn you out, and keep pushing you til you break. Was forced to do two separate jobs because they are too cheap to rehire positions.

pros: Getting Educated on critical thinking, problem solving and being employable you.
cons: you spend lots of time there from classes to work.  Sometimes I'm their all day long until 8-9 pm

review_title: I loved Working Here in Richmond, VA
pros: Everyone was like family here. Very friendly professional atmosphere. You can tell they all really care about the work they do with the students.
cons: There weren't any cons during my tenure.

pros: Supportive, friendly, genuinely caring community. Students have many resources to take advantage of. Invested employees are noticed and appreciated.
cons: Faculty salaries are low for some reason across all of the campuses.

pros: Supportive and passionate staff that want to see their students succeed
cons: Focus of the company is not always on the students who need the support the most but on those who have the best chance of success

pros: Gaining accredited knowledge in the business administration program that's useful to many employers.
cons: There is no guaranteed that the accreditation will uphold to employers standards.

job_title: Library Student Assistant in Cleveland, OH
pros: Primary responsibility was to be presence at refernce desk.  Assist patron who are searching for both printed and electronic resources.
cons: No cons for a lifetime learner.

pros: They believe in the students and really help with preparing them for the workplace. Staff is friendly and student centred. Good pay and paid time off.
cons: long hourse and working holidays. Health insurance is expensive.

job_title: Allied Health Faculty in Orchard Park, NY
pros: Allied Health Faculty full-time, good salary, could be more for working 3-15 week semesters.  Great compensation for extra classes, nice class sizes.
cons: Working 3-15 semesters for same pay as other 2 semester colleges

job_title: Librarian's Assistant (Work Study) in Norfolk, VA
pros:
My supervisor is very accommodating. 
There is very little pressure in my position (I am a student work study).
cons: The budget always seems to be a major factor in who stays and who goes.

pros: Very supportive, extremely positive, teamwork encouraged, uplifting, customer-centric
cons: Only con is there could be better communication between departments

review_title: I have worked here for over ten years.
pros: The working conditions are good, and the work-life balance is reasonable.
cons: Lack of promotional opportunities; lots of change going on currently

pros: Family Friendly environment,  great culture.
cons: only downside is that you need to keep your work load boundaries. Team work culture is great until the lines blur too far. And they can.

pros: The students are highly diverse. The staff is committed to student's success including raising the graduation rate and assisting even more students succeed.
cons: Would love to have more classes and hours.

pros: Really do help students and has a lot to offer students!
cons: Advancement is stifled and no incentive to do well.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in Prince George, VA
pros: Family atmosphere and small enough to have direct contact with every student
cons: Not a lot of training

pros: Some classes are graded by rubrics.
cons: Not strong in IT;  need talent in professors... may have changed since 2012.

pros: Decent compensation compared to local public colleges, supportive administration.  They offer many opportunities to tutor students at no additional cost to them.
cons: Many classes are scheduled late in evening.

pros: This is a great place to work with dedicated faculty. Some flexibility with scheduling. You have some input in your schedule.
cons:
- Lower wage than some schools
- Shorter breaks

pros: Nice place to work, Very cooperative and nice colleagues. I enjoy working there
cons: I could not find any cons as I did not come across one.

pros: Education based corporation for profit
cons: Low, low employee pay.  Too few employees to handle volume of responsibilities- burn out occurs sooner than later

pros: Great pay, spa trips, and impeccable recognition and respect (**if you work in the Admissions Department)
cons: Unless you work in upper manangement or Admissions, you are doomed. The lack of respect, integrity, competence, and employee appreciation will continue to drive this company down.

review_title: Promises are made and not kept
job_title: Senior Admissions Representative in Cleveland, OH
pros: The environment at one time wad adaptable.
cons: Micro - managed.  Everyone is replaceable.

pros: Its good for one on one and must of the teachers are willing to help you
cons: some of the programs don't give a lot off support.

pros: Flexible course schedules and more of interactive teaching experience dealing with students one on one.
cons: Enrollment numbers decline frequently in the business programs

job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Tonawanda, NY
pros: Relaxing environment, friendly and professional staff, good pay and benefits.
cons: Honestly, there is nothing that is negative about Bryant and Stratton College.

pros:
Decent salary and single medical benefits
Varied work schedule; somewhat flexible
cons: Small Department Staffing; heavy workloads

pros: Great college to work with, the staff presents a great atmosphere.
cons: Residential life department is relatively new, still getting up on it's feet.

pros: Do you job and make goal and you will do great.
cons: Don't make goal.. depends who you are..you could still be there or not.

pros: The students are really great, especially those who want to learn.
cons: The management is all politics.

job_title: Career Development Specialist in Eastlake, OH
pros:
Satisfaction from helping students
Good vacation time
Good benefits
cons:
Poor Middle Management
Not many advancement opportunities
Hard to get raises

pros: Caring atmosphere and room for growth.
cons: Still a for profit atmosphere

job_title: Data Analyst in Orchard Park, NY
pros: Great tuition reimbursement: but they have made it harder to qualify for.
cons:
Fire people who realize they are trying to give employees raises that are half what they should be.
Management makes you feel thot you should feel lucky to have a job.
Benefits are expensive!

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Toledo, OH
pros: Easy class preparation and decent classroom environment.
cons: Very low pay. School is a borderline scam because students take out huge loans with big promises of future employment when they can get equal or even better career course at a community college.

pros: Great to learn customer service experience. Also, allows time to get assignments done.
cons: Bored when all assignments are done

job_title: Career Services Assistant in Eastlake, OH
pros: Gained great experience in the HR field
cons: None that I can think of off hand

job_title: Subject Area Coordinator in Orchard Park, NY
pros: People are friendly and considerate
cons: Stressful environment, Cut backs are hitting all departments hard

pros: the pros are the people you work with
cons: no cons to this particular position

job_title: Student Library Assistant in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Very engaging atmosphere to work in. Feels like family!
cons: I really enjoyed working here, therefore, no cons.

job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Virginia Beach, VA
pros: Co workers and the relationships you build

pros: Relaxed, driven environment to meet goals

Helping Students further their education!
Great People!

job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Wauwatosa, WI

review_title: Admissions shouldn't be a sales job.
pros: I had my own office and business cards.
cons: I signed people up for expensive college classes that they were not interested in taking and had no intentions of paying back their student loans.

pros: learned a lot over time
cons: hard to advance.  Limited opportunities

job_title: Nursing Faculty in Maple Heights, OH
pros: good company to work for
cons: no complaints about the position

review_title: The reason why proprietary institutions should not exist
pros: It's a job, which is not much to stand on.
cons: Unethical business practices; unethical managers; lack of forethought of looming business cycles; poor or low pay; horrible health insurance.

job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Decent pay and great colleagues.
cons: Benefits minimal, high insurance premium, detrimental work environment, no room for professional growth.

pros: It's a job...not hard work...nice offices....holidays off...decent pay...good food...free parking....steady employment
cons: Expensive benefits. ...evening hours...weekend hours....not much training....strange business practices. ...competition
